The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) published a guidance in 2010 regarding the disclosure requirements for companies to address climate change (U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, 2010). This guidance mandated that companies issuing stocks on U.S. markets disclose any risks and uncertainties related to climate change, including physical impacts on assets and supply chains, legislative impacts on profit generation, international accords affecting raw material prices, and indirect market consequences such as supply and demand (Doran & Quinn, 2008). Although this was a step forward in transparency and accountability, the problem remains that SEC filings are lengthy and filled with financial and legislative jargon, making it difficult to pinpoint passages addressing climate risk disclosures. A 2013 study found that only 27% of 3,895 U.S. public companies listed on major stock exchanges mentioned climate change explicitly in their annual reports (Hirji, 2013). However, this study used keyword search, which leaves room for a more in-depth analysis using Natural Language Processing (NLP) to identify which companies disclose various types of climate risk and to what extent.

Our study aims to focus on a subset of major U.S. companies to analyze the extent to which these companies disclose climate risk, what they divulge, and how this evolves before and after the 2010 ruling. We propose to analyze 10-K reports, which are publicly available documents published on the SEC website, providing a comprehensive summary of a company's financial performance on a yearly basis. We will focus on companies from the S&P 500, the largest companies listed on the U.S. stock markets, representing about 80% of their total market value. We will specifically focus on companies from sectors most obviously impacted by climate change: energy, real estate, oil and gas, utilities, and materials (Winn et al., 2011), for a total of 115 companies. We will target the ten-year period between 2008 and 2018, encompassing a time frame before and since the SEC ruling. This will give us a total of 1150 documents to analyze.

To identify climate disclosure sections, we propose a semi-supervised approach, constructing a climate dictionary from a small set of seed words selected manually, then automatically expanding these seed words to build a full-fledged vocabulary. The eight initial seed words are: biodiversity, carbon, climate, ecology, environment, emission, pollution, and sustainable. We will use a 300-dimensional word embedding model trained on Wikipedia and the Gigaword corpus (Pennington et al., 2014) to generate one vector per word and retrieve the ten closest words using cosine similarity, expanding the initial list of 8 seed words into 50 climate-related words. This expanded list includes terms like CO2 and deforestation.
